0.25.text:
>> Baroness Howells: I am absolutely honoured
to have been asked to talk about Baroness

9.37.text:
Amos.
She was among the first women peers, black

15.98.text:
women peers, in the House. And she came in
in 1997 and it was a real pleasure when her

26.45.text:
portrait was commissioned by the arts committee
in the House and now she hangs in the corridor

34.07.text:
near the Lords bar.
I chose that place for her so I am very pleased

39.96.text:
about that. Why I like where it's hanging
is because opposite is a huge picture, artist

49.59.text:
impression, of the House of Lords before women
ever were allowed in the chamber.

62.01.text:
>> Baroness Howells: I still keep looking
at it and wondering 'how did the artist bring

67.31.text:
out her character so well?'
The detail itself is absolutely beautiful.

73.86.text:
There couldn't have been a clearer portrait
of her, this is Valerie. She brings peace,

82.98.text:
but there is an awful lot of strength. The
strength is actually reflected in the fact

88.43.text:
that she chose to wear the kente cloth.
The chair I am told is one of the chairs in

96.84.text:
the artist's studio and although it looks
very suspiciously like a House of Lords chair,

102.93.text:
it isn't. Her jewellery comes from Ghana,
we all know that Ghana has got lots of gold

111.38.text:
and I am not surprised that she chose to wear
it on that day.

118.47.text:
She is straight forward and you can see that
in her, that you know she will take no nonsense,

125.13.text:
but I think one can say by her folded arms
in that portrait that she isn't someone who

131.62.text:
will raise her voice, she will calmly deal
with all the processes, so it was no surprise

138.07.text:
that she rose to become the leader of the
House of Lords.

143.13.text:
>> Baroness Howells: She had Paul Benney as
the artist. And even though he appears to

153.48.text:
have started his career as a portrait painter
later in life, it's a true reflection of her.
